NewsDetail.Name: Teaching One Another Online
NewsDetail.Title: Teaching One Another Online
NewsDetail.Abstract: Online classes at BYU-Idaho share the same format as the Learning Model, which encourages students to prepare, teach one another, and ponder/prove what they have learned. How does that work exactly online?
NewsDetail.Author: Justin Murdock
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
A major component of BYU-Idaho's Learning Model is that we should teach one another. Scripture teaches us: "And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit to faithful men who shall be able to teach others also" (2 Tim. 2:2). Teachers treasure up knowledge in the hope of sharing what they learn with their students. As students interact with one another they should work to strengthen the knowledge and understanding of their peers.


Online classes at BYU-Idaho share the same format as the Learning Model, which encourages students to prepare, teach one another, and ponder/prove what they have learned. Interaction between students online is facilitated through the use of discussion boards, video chats, and emails. Students should feel included and free to interact in an environment where questions may be asked, and discussion may be open and free.


Although these interactions are not in person, many students who do not live in Rexburg find such a system to be a tremendous blessing. Online classes are not just a series of assignments and due-dates, but a workable format for facilitating the needs and situations of BYU-Idaho students in various locations. Students who have participated in online classes extol some of the programs virtues: "It is such a different spirit taking these classes, rather than the ones I have taken at the community college," says Kim Johnstone. "It all comes from the clean language, and not having to worry about the topics discussed." Our hope is that students who participate in online classes will take the opportunity to engage in discussion, and work to build up their peers in class.
